content:
Mohan Nataraj, a pure mathematician, theoretical computer scientist and software developer with 5 years of experience from silicon valley of India, Bangalore. I‚Äôm currently working in an early stage startup - designing and developing. I do lead myself with great confidence and believe in the following,  
 "It is by his activities and not by enjoyment that man feels he is alive. In idleness we not only feel that life is fleeting, but we also feel lifeless‚Äù -Immanuel kant    Philosophy through experience has always been my innate belief. While it is aberrant for a pure mathematician to say I believe in GOD my experiences in life would otherwise prove so.
My research interests include distribution in prime numbers, optimization, mathematical modeling, analysis and any programmable matter.
Two of my most fervent personal research project; I persevere on are Riemann hypothesis and computer aided drug development for CANCER.
 Member of American Mathematical Society (Carleton University)[2019-2020]   Member of IEEE (Illinois Tech) [2012-present]
summary: Mohan Nataraj, a pure mathematician, theoretical computer scientist and software developer with 5 years of experience from silicon valley of India, Bangalore. I‚Äôm currently working in an early stage startup - designing and developing.
title: Mohan Nataraj

content:
Flexibility This feature can be used for publishing content such as:
 Online courses Project or software documentation Tutorials  The courses folder may be renamed. For example, we can rename it to docs for software/project documentation or tutorials for creating an online course.
Delete tutorials To remove these pages, delete the courses folder and see below to delete the associated menu link.
Update site menu After renaming or deleting the courses folder, you may wish to update any [[main]] menu links to it by editing your menu configuration at config/_default/menus.toml.
For example, if you delete this folder, you can remove the following from your menu configuration:
[[main]] name = "Courses" url = "courses/" weight = 50  Or, if you are creating a software documentation site, you can rename the courses folder to docs and update the associated Courses menu configuration to:
[[main]] name = "Docs" url = "docs/" weight = 50  Update the docs menu If you use the docs layout, note that the name of the menu in the front matter should be in the form [menu.X] where X is the folder name. Hence, if you rename the courses/example/ folder, you should also rename the menu definitions in the front matter of files within courses/example/ from [menu.example] to [menu.<NewFolderName>].
summary: Basics of javascript language for future reference. Most of them are referenced from [w3school](https://www.w3schools.com/js/)

title: Example Page 2

content:
Whilst “Bridges” are built to span through obstacles, the preceding statement was quite erring in the city of K√∂nigsberg in Prussia (now Kaliningrad, Russia) during the 18th century. Here we talk about the inception of Graph Theory, it’s application to the real world problems and a famous puzzle asked during my childhood. The blog also contain a pretty good talk given by a math student below in Chaos Computer Club congression.
During the 18th century in the city of K√∂nigsberg the land masses were connected by seven bridges. The problem or challenge in the city was to walk or traverse through the seven bridges only once, i.e; to walk atmost only once on all the bridges. While the challenge was talk of the town during the period, we show on how Leonhard Euler approached the problem that actually gave rise to “Graph Theory”.
  left to right city of K√∂nigsberg converted into graph (graph theory)   The right most part of the image shows on how the land masses and bridges are converted into graph theoretic notation. The land masses are represented by a circle or commonly called “Node or Vertex” and the line connecting two nodes is called an “Edge”. An edge commonly defines a relationship between two nodes and they always connect two nodes. The last term to know is degree of a node which is actually the number of edges or lines incident on a node or vertex. Now since we got the basics of Graph Theory before diving into Euler’s solution I would like share the childhood puzzle, well that’s why the whole blog started out to be.
While in the 90’s and early 2000’s my city Bangalore or more infamously known as Garden City or Land of 1000 lakes was absolutely a great city & time to grow and have fun (name it from sport, education to being a cool kid you had it all). whoever you were one of the famous puzzle or challenge thrown at us was to draw the below image without lifting your pen or pencil and most importantly you cannot pass over the line already drawn i.e; you cannot pass a line twice.
  figure to draw (familiar?)   While the above can be converted into graph theoretical notation, just as how Leonhard Euler did it. Well here is how, we can convert it by drawing circle or vertices or nodes at the four corners of the square and consider the line joining them as edges (curved lines are also edges). Now if you have tried solving the above you know that it is not possible to complete the following diagram, but almost possible well you may just miss one edge out of 10 (try). The explanation here is quite easy, I shall let you think with a hint “degree of vertex” well I hope that you paid attention to that term above to be more precise atleast two vertices or nodes or circles should have what number of degree’s (odd or even)? Hmmm!! Well did that just reveal the answer, hope not!!. But hey, just so you did not get the above story that’s absolutely fine see the video below to know more about Euler’s solution to K√∂nigsberg problem:
    I hope you got it now, oh well there is always something about old white men and being genius got to blame Einstein. [üòõ] For more entertainment and want to know more about graph theory and video games as “we cool kids” love playing PC games. Here is a video from Chaos Computer Club
 The above video does have some very cool content if you are into topology, . The real world application of graph theory is quite immense due to its simplicity, it ranges from waking across the 18th century bridges to current navigation technology, yep that’s right google maps does use it. You can also use it for scheduling airplanes, project management, production management and hey what’s more important than scheduling your life ?
 update better links if exists on internet later Wiki - Seven Bridges Wiki - Topology
summary: Whilst “Bridges” are built to span through obstacles, the preceding statement was quite erring in the city of K√∂nigsberg in Prussia (now Kaliningrad, Russia) during the 18th century. Here we talk about the inception of Graph Theory, it’s application to the real world problems and a famous puzzle asked during my childhood.
title: Childhood Puzzle Solved
